category.text: $module$/top/Default for 10.3 The Exponential Form of a Complex Number

info.text: The default category for questions shared in context '10.3 The Exponential Form of a Complex Number'.

name.text: 10.3.1.1 Series expansions for exponential and trigonometric functions

questiontext.text:
Series expansions for exponential and trigonometric functions Rekkeutvikling for eksponensielle og trigonometriske funksjoner.

We have, so far, considered two ways of representing a complex number: \[\qquad z=a+i b\qquad \text{Cartesian form}\]or \[\qquad z=r(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta)\qquad \text{polar form}\]In this quiz we introduce a third way of denoting a complex number: the exponential form. Hittil har vi vurdert to måter å representere et komplekst tall på: \[\qquad z=a+i b\qquad \text{Kartesisk form}\] eller \[\qquad z=r(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta)\qquad \text{polar form}\] I denne quizen introduserer vi en tredje måte å representere et komplekst tall på: den eksponentielle formen.

If \(x\) is a real number then, as we shall verify in a later quiz, the exponential number \(e\) raised to the power \(x\) can be written as a series of powers of \(x\):\[\qquad e^x=1+x+{x^2\over {2!}}+{x^3\over {3!}}+{x^4\over {4!}}+\cdots\]in which \(n!=n(n-1)(n-2)\dots (3)(2)(1)\) is the factorial of the integer \(n\). Although there are an infinite number of terms on the right-hand side, in any practical calculation we could only use a finite number. For example if we choose \(x=1\) (and taking only six terms) then\[\begin{aligned} e^1 &\approx 1+1+{1\over {2!}}+{1\over {3!}}+{1\over {4!}}+{1\over {5!}}\\&= 2+0.5+0.16666+0.04166+0.00833\\&=2.71666\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\end{aligned}\] which is fairly close to the accurate value of \(e=2.71828\) (to 5 d.p.) Hvis \(x\) er et reelt tall, kan eksponentialtallet \(e\) opphøyd i \(x\) skrives som en rekke polynomer av \(x\), noe vi vil verifisere senere i en quiz: \[\qquad e^x=1+x+{x^2\over {2!}}+{x^3\over {3!}}+{x^4\over {4!}}+\cdots\] der \(n!=n(n-1)(n-2)\dots(3)(2)(1)\) er falkultet av tallet \textit{n}. Selv om det er et uendelig antall ledd på høyresiden, vil vi i praksis kun bruke et endelig antall ledd. For eksempel, hvis vi velger \(x=1\) (og tar kun med seks ledd), så vil \[\begin{aligned} e^1 &\approx 1+1+{1\over {2!}}+{1\over {3!}}+{1\over {4!}}+{1\over {5!}}\\&= 2+0.5+0.16666+0.04166+0.00833\\&=2.71666\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\end{aligned}\] som er ganske nær den nøyaktige verdien av \(e=2.71828\) (med 5 desimaler).

We ask you to accept that \(e^x\), for any real value of \(x\), is the same as \(\displaystyle{1+x+{x^2\over {2!}}+{x^3\over {3!}}+\cdots }\) and that if we wish to calculate \(e^x\) for a particular value of \(x\) we will only take a finite number of terms in the series. Obviously the more terms we take in any particular calculation the more accurate will be our calculation. Vi ber deg om å akseptere at \(e^x\), for hvilken som helst reell verdi av \(x\), er det samme som \(\displaystyle{1+x+{x^2\over {2!}}+{x^3\over {3!}}+\cdots}\) og at hvis vi ønsker å beregne \(e^x\) for en bestemt verdi av \(x\), vil vi bare ta et endelig antall ledd i serien. Åpenbart vil jo flere ledd vi tar med i en beregning, jo være mer presis vil vår beregning være.

As we shall also see later, similar series expansions exist for the trigonometric functions \(\sin x\) and \(\cos x\): \[\qquad \sin x=x-{x^3\over {3!}}+{x^5\over {5!}}-{x^7\over {7!}}+\cdots\]\[\qquad \cos x=1-{x^2\over {2!}}+{x^4\over {4!}}-{x^6\over {6!}}+\cdots\]in which \(x\) is measured in radians. Som vi også senere skal se, finnes det tilsvarende rekkeutviklinger for de trigonometriske funksjonene \(\sin x\) og \(\cos x\): \[\qquad \sin x=x-{x^3\over {3!}}+{x^5\over {5!}}-{x^7\over {7!}}+\cdots\]\[\qquad \cos x=1-{x^2\over {2!}}+{x^4\over {4!}}-{x^6\over {6!}}+\cdots\]der \(x\) måles i radianer.

The observant reader will see that these two series for \(\sin x\) and \(\cos x\) are similar to the series for \(e^x\). Through the use of the symbol \(i\) (where \(i^2=-1)\) we will examine this close correspondence. Den observante leseren vil se at disse to rekkefølger for \(\sin x\) og \(\cos x\) ligner på rekkefølgen for \(e^x\). Ved bruk av symbolet \(i\) (hvor \(i^2=-1)\) vil vi undersøke denne nære sammenhengen.

In the series for \(e^x\) replace \(x\) on both left-hand and right-hand sides by \(i\theta\) to give: \[\qquad e^{i\theta}=1+(i\theta)+{(i\theta)^2\over {2!}}+{(i\theta)^3\over {3!}}+{(i\theta)^4\over {4!}}+{(i\theta)^5\over {5!}}+\cdots\]Then, as usual, replace every occurrence of \(i^2\) by \(-1\) to give \[\qquad e^{i\theta}=1+i\theta-{\theta^2\over {2!}}-i{\theta^3\over {3!}}+{\theta^4\over {4!}}+i{\theta^5\over {5!}}+\cdots\] I serien for \(e^x\), erstatt \(x\) på både venstre- og høyre side med \(i\theta\) for å få: \[\qquad e^{i\theta}=1+(i\theta)+{(i\theta)^2\over {2!}}+{(i\theta)^3\over {3!}}+{(i\theta)^4\over {4!}}+{(i\theta)^5\over {5!}}+\cdots\]Deretter, som vanlig, bytt ut hver forekomst av \(i^2\) med \(-1\) for å få \[\qquad e^{i\theta}=1+i\theta-{\theta^2\over {2!}}-i{\theta^3\over {3!}}+{\theta^4\over {4!}}+i{\theta^5\over {5!}}+\cdots\]

which, when re-organised into real and imaginary terms gives, finally: \[\begin{aligned} e^{i\theta}&=\left[1-{\theta^2\over {2!}}+{\theta^4\over {4!}}-\cdots \right]+i\left[ \theta-{\theta^3\over {3!}}+{\theta^5\over {5!}}-\cdots \right]\\ &=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta.\end{aligned}\] som, når den er reorganisert i reelle og imaginære termer, endelig gir: \[\begin{aligned} e^{i\theta}&=\left[1-{\theta^2\over {2!}}+{\theta^4\over {4!}}-\cdots \right]+i\left[ \theta-{\theta^3\over {3!}}+{\theta^5\over {5!}}-\cdots \right]\\ &=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta.\end{aligned}\]

Key Point Nøkkelpunkt.

\(e^{i\theta} = \cos\theta+i\sin\theta\) .

Example Eksempel

Find complex number expressions, in Cartesian form, for  Finn uttrykkene for komplekse tall, i kartesisk form, for

  1. \({e^{i\pi /4}}\qquad\)
  2. \(e^{-i}\qquad\)
  3. \(e^{i\pi}\)

Solution Løsning

We use the above Key Point: Vi bruker det overstående nøkkelpunktet:

  1. \(\displaystyle{e^{i\pi/4} = \cos\frac{\pi}{4} + i\sin\frac{\pi}{4} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} + i\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}\)
  2. \(e^{-i} = \cos{(-1)} + i\sin{(-1)} \approx 0.540 - i(0.841)\). Don't forget: use radians. \(e^{-i} = \cos{(-1)} + i\sin{(-1)} \approx 0.540 - i(0.841)\). Ikke glem: bruk radianer.
  4. \(e^{i\pi} = \cos\pi + i\sin\pi = -1+i(0) = -1\)

The exponential form Den eksponentielle formen

Since \(z=r(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta )\) and since \(e^{i\theta}=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta\) we therefore obtain another way in which to denote a complex number: \(z=re^{i\theta}\), called the exponential form. Siden \(z=r(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta )\) og siden \(e^{i\theta}=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta\), får vi en annen måte å betegne et komplekst tall på: \(z=re^{i\theta}\), kalt den eksponentielle formen.

Key Point Nøkkelpunkt

The exponential form of a complex number is \[z = re^{i\theta}\quad\text{in which}\quad r=|z|\quad\text{and}\quad\theta=\text{arg}(z)\] so \[z=re^{i\theta}=r(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta)\] Den eksponentielle formen til et komplekst tall er \[z = re^{i\theta}\quad\text{der}\quad r=|z|\quad\text{og}\quad\theta=\text{arg}(z)\] så \[z=re^{i\theta}=r(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta)\]

Example Eksempel

If \(z = re^{i\theta}\) and \(w = te^{i\phi}\) then find expressions for Hvis \(z = re^{i\theta}\) og \(w = te^{i\phi}\), finn uttrykk for

  1.  \(z^{-1}\) 
  2.  \(z^*\) 
  3.  \(zw\)

Solution Løsning

  1. If \(z = re^{i\theta}\) then \[z^{-1} = \frac{1}{re^{i\theta}} = \frac{1}{r}e^{-i\theta}\] using the normal rules for indices. Hvis \(z = re^{i\theta}\) så er \[z^{-1} = \frac{1}{re^{i\theta}} = \frac{1}{r}e^{-i\theta}\] ved å bruke de normale reglene for eksponenter.
  2. Working in polar form: if \(z = re^{i\theta} = r(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta) \) then \[z^* = r(\cos\theta - i\sin\theta) = r(cos(-\theta) + i\sin(-\theta)) = re^{-i\theta}\] since \(\cos(-\theta) = \cos{\theta}\) and \(\sin(-\theta) = -\sin{\theta}\). In fact this reflects the general rule: to find the complex conjugate of any expression simply replace the \(i\) by \(-i\) wherever it occurs in the expression. I polar form: hvis \(z = re^{i\theta} = r(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta) \) så er \[z^* = r(\cos\theta - i\sin\theta) = r(cos(-\theta) + i\sin(-\theta)) = re^{-i\theta}\] siden \(\cos(-\theta) = \cos{\theta}\) og \(\sin(-\theta) = -\sin{\theta}\).
  3. \( zw = (re^{i\theta})(te^{i\phi}) = rte^{i\theta}e^{i\phi} = rte^{i\theta + i\phi} = rte^{i(\theta + \phi)} \) which is again the result we are familiar with: when complex numbers are multiplied their moduli multiply and their arguments add. \( zw = (re^{i\theta})(te^{i\phi}) = rte^{i\theta}e^{i\phi} = rte^{i\theta + i\phi} = rte^{i(\theta + \phi)} \) som igjen er resultatet vi er kjent med: når komplekse tall multipliseres så multipliseres deres modulus og deres argumenter adderes.

We see that in some circumstances the exponential form is even more convenient than the polar form since we need not worry about cumbersome trigonometric relations. Vi ser at i noen situasjoner er den eksponentielle formen enda mer praktisk enn den polare formen siden vi ikke trenger å bekymre oss for vanskelige trigonometriske forhold.

Hyperbolic and trigonometric functions Hyperbolske og trigonometriske funksjoner

We have seen previously that \[\qquad e^{i\theta}=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta\] It follows from this that \[\qquad e^{-i\theta}=\cos (-\theta)+i\sin (-\theta)=\cos\theta -i\sin\theta\] Now if we add these two relations together we obtain \[\qquad \cos\theta ={e^{i\theta}+e^{-i\theta}\over {2}}\] whereas if we subtract the second from the first we have\[\qquad \sin\theta ={e^{i\theta}-e^{-i\theta}\over {2i}}\] These new relations are reminiscent of the hyperbolic functions introduced in a previous quiz. There we defined \(\cosh x\) and \(\sinh x\) in terms of the exponential function: \[\qquad \cosh x ={e^{x}+e^{-x}\over {2}}\qquad \sinh x ={e^{x}-e^{-x}\over {2}}\] In fact, if we replace \(x\) by \(i\theta\) in these last two equations we obtain \[\qquad \cosh (i\theta) ={e^{i\theta } +e^{-i\theta}\over 2}\equiv \cos \theta\qquad \text{and}\qquad \sinh (i\theta) ={e^{i\theta } -e^{-i\theta}\over 2}\equiv i\sin \theta\] Although, by our notation, we have implied that both \(x\) and \(\theta\) are real quantities in fact these expressions for \(\cosh\) and \(\sinh\) in terms of \(\cos\) and \(\sin\) are quite general. Vi har tidligere sett at \[\qquad e^{i\theta}=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta\] Dermed følger det at \[\qquad e^{-i\theta}=\cos (-\theta)+i\sin (-\theta)=\cos\theta -i\sin\theta\] Hvis vi nå legger disse to sammen, får vi \[\qquad \cos\theta ={e^{i\theta}+e^{-i\theta}\over {2}}\] Hvis vi derimot trekker den andre fra den første, får vi\[\qquad \sin\theta ={e^{i\theta}-e^{-i\theta}\over {2i}}\] Disse nye forholdene minner om de hyperbolske funksjonene som ble introdusert i en tidligere quiz. Der definerte vi \(\cosh x\) og \(\sinh x\) i forhold til eksponentialfunksjonen: \[\qquad \cosh x ={e^{x}+e^{-x}\over {2}}\qquad \sinh x ={e^{x}-e^{-x}\over {2}}\] Faktisk, hvis vi erstatter \(x\) med \(i\theta\) i de siste to likningene, får vi \[\qquad \cosh (i\theta) ={e^{i\theta } +e^{-i\theta}\over 2}\equiv \cos \theta\qquad \text{og}\qquad \sinh (i\theta) ={e^{i\theta } -e^{-i\theta}\over 2}\equiv i\sin \theta\] Selv om vi ved vår notasjon har antydet at både \(x\) og \(\theta\) er reelle størrelser, er disse uttrykkene for \(\cosh\) og \(\sinh\) i forhold til \(\cos\) og \(\sin\) ganske generelle.

Key Point Nøkkelpunkt

If \(z\) is any complex number then \[\cosh(iz) \equiv \cos z\quad\text{and}\quad\sinh(iz) \equiv i\sin z\] Equivalently, replacing \(z\) by \(iz\): \[\cosh z \equiv \cos(iz) \quad\text{and}\quad i\sinh z \equiv \sin(iz)\] Hvis \(z\) er et komplekst tall så gjelder følgende: \[\cosh(iz) \equiv \cos z\quad\text{og}\quad\sinh(iz) \equiv i\sin z\] Ekvivalent kan man erstatte \(z\) med \(iz\) og få: \[\cosh z \equiv \cos(iz) \quad\text{og}\quad i\sinh z \equiv \sin(iz)\]

Further analysis similar to that in Exercise 3 leads to Osborne's rule. Videre analyse lignende den i øving 3 leder oss til Osbornes regel.

Key Point Nøkkelpunkt.

Hyperbolic function identities are obtained from trigonometric function identities by replacing \(\sin\theta\) by \(\sinh\theta\) and \(\cos\theta\) by \(\cosh\theta\) except that every occurrence of \(\sin^2\theta\) is replaced by \(-\sinh^2\theta\). This is known as Osborne's Rule. Hyperbolske funksjonsidentiteter blir funnet fra trigonometriske funksjonsidentiteter ved å erstatte \(\sin\theta\) med \(\sinh\theta\) og \(\cos\theta\) med \(\cosh\theta\), unntatt at hver forekomst av \(\sin^2\theta\) blir erstattet med \(-\sinh^2\theta\). Dette kalles Osborne's regel.

Example Eksempel

Use Osborne's rule to obtain the hyperbolic identity equivalent to \(1 + \tan^2\theta \equiv \sec^2\theta\). Bruk Osbornes regel for å få den hyperbolske identiteten som tilsvarer \(1 + \tan^2\theta \equiv \sec^2\theta\).

Solution Løsning

Here \(1 + \tan^2\theta \equiv \sec^2\theta\) is equivalent to \(\displaystyle{1 + \frac{\sin^2\theta}{\cos^2\theta} \equiv \frac{1}{\cos^2\theta}}\) . Hence if \[\sin^2\theta \mapsto -\sinh^2\theta\qquad\text{and}\qquad \cos^2\theta \mapsto \cosh^2\theta\] then we obtain \[1 - \frac{\sinh^2\theta}{\cosh^2\theta} \equiv \frac{1}{\cosh^2\theta}\qquad\text{or, equivalently,}\qquad 1 - \tanh^2\theta \equiv \text{sech}^2\theta.\] Her er \(1 + \tan^2\theta \equiv \sec^2\theta\) lik \(\displaystyle{1 + \frac{\sin^2\theta}{\cos^2\theta} \equiv \frac{1}{\cos^2\theta}}\). Dermed, hvis \[\sin^2\theta \mapsto -\sinh^2\theta\qquad\text{og}\qquad \cos^2\theta \mapsto \cosh^2\theta\], så får vi \[1 - \frac{\sinh^2\theta}{\cosh^2\theta} \equiv \frac{1}{\cosh^2\theta}\qquad\text{eller, tilsvarende,}\qquad 1 - \tanh^2\theta \equiv \text{sech}^2\theta.\]

Feedback applied to an amplifier Tilbakekobling på en forsterker.

Feedback is applied to an amplifier such that \[\qquad A'=\dfrac{A}{1-\beta A}\] where \(A', A\) and \(\beta\) are complex quantities. \(A\) is the amplifier gain, \(A'\) is the gain with feedback and \(\beta\) is the proportion of the output which has been fed back. Tilbakekobling på en forsterker blir anvendt slik at \[\qquad A'=\dfrac{A}{1-\beta A}\] hvor \(A', A\) og \(\beta\) er komplekse størrelser. \(A\) er amplifikasjonen til forsterken, \(A'\) er forsterkningen med tilbakekobling og \(\beta\) er andelen av utgangssignalet som har blitt sendt tilbake.

  1. If at 30 Hz, \(A=-500\) and \(\beta=0.005e^{8\pi i /9}\), calculate \(A'\) in exponential form. Hvis ved 30 Hz, \(A=-500\) og \(\beta=0.005e^{8\pi i /9}\), beregn \(A'\) i eksponentiell form.
  2. At a particular frequency it is desired to have \(A'=300e^{5\pi i /9}\) where it is known that \(A=400e^{11\pi i /18}\). Find the value of \(\beta\) necessary to achieve this gain modification. På en bestemt frekvens er det ønskelig å ha \(A'=300e^{5\pi i /9}\) hvor det er kjent at \(A=400e^{11\pi i /18}\). Finn verdien av \(\beta\) som er nødvendig for å oppnå denne forsterkningsmodifikasjonen.

Mathematical statement of the problem Matematisk uttalelse av problemet.

  1. Substitute \(A=-500\) and \(\beta=0.005e^{8\pi i /9}\) into \(A'=\dfrac{A}{1-\beta A}\) in order to find \(A'\). Sett \(A=-500\) og \(\beta=0.005e^{8\pi i /9}\) inn i \(A'=\dfrac{A}{1-\beta A}\) for å finne \(A'\).
  2. We need to solve for \(\beta\) when \(A'=300e^{5\pi i /9}\) and \(A=400e^{11\pi i /18}\). Vi må løse for \(\beta\) når \(A'=300e^{5\pi i /9}\) og \(A=400e^{11\pi i /18}\).

Mathematical analysis Matematisk analyse

  1. We have \[A'=\dfrac{A}{1-\beta A}=\dfrac{-500}{1-0.005e^{8\pi i /9}\times (-500)}=\dfrac{-500}{1+2.5e^{8\pi i /9}}\] Expressing the bottom line of this expression in Cartesian form this becomes: \[\qquad A'=\dfrac{-500}{1+2.5\cos\left(\dfrac{8\pi}{9}\right)+2.5i\sin\left(\dfrac{8\pi}{9}\right)}\approx \dfrac{-500}{-1.349+0.855i}\] Expressing both the top and bottom lines in exponential form we get: \[\qquad A'\approx\dfrac{500e^{i\pi}}{1.597e^{i 2.576}}\approx 313e^{0.566i}\] Vi har \[A'=\dfrac{A}{1-\beta A}=\dfrac{-500}{1-0.005e^{8\pi i /9}\times (-500)}=\dfrac{-500}{1+2.5e^{8\pi i /9}}\] Ved å uttrykke nevneren av dette uttrykket i kartesisk form blir dette: \[\qquad A'=\dfrac{-500}{1+2.5\cos\left(\dfrac{8\pi}{9}\right)+2.5i\sin\left(\dfrac{8\pi}{9}\right)}\approx \dfrac{-500}{-1.349+0.855i}\] Ved å uttrykke både teller og nevner i eksponentiell form får vi: \[\qquad A'\approx\dfrac{500e^{i\pi}}{1.597e^{i 2.576}}\approx 313e^{0.566i}\]
  2. We have \[A'=\dfrac{A}{1-\beta A}\rightarrow A'(1-\beta A)=A\rightarrow -\beta AA'=A-A'\] and \[\text{i.e.}\qquad \beta=\dfrac{A'-A}{AA'}\rightarrow\beta=\dfrac{1}{A}-\dfrac{1}{A'}\] So \[\beta=\dfrac{1}{A}-\dfrac{1}{A'}=\dfrac{1}{400e^{11\pi i /18}}-\dfrac{1}{300e^{5\pi i /9}}\approx 0.0025e^{-11\pi i/18}-0.00333e^{-5\pi i /9}\] Expressing both complex numbers in Cartesian form gives \[\beta = 0.0025\cos\left(-\dfrac{11\pi}{18}\right)+0.0025i\sin \left(-\dfrac{11\pi}{18}\right)\] \[\qquad-0.00333\cos \left(-\dfrac{5\pi}{9}\right)-0.00333i\sin \left(-\dfrac{5\pi}{9}\right)\] \[=-2.768\times 10^{-4}+9.3017\times 10^{-4}i=9.7048\times 10^{-4}e^{1.86i}\] So to 3 significant figures \(\beta=9.70\times 10^{-4}e^{1.86i}\) Vi har \[A'=\dfrac{A}{1-\beta A}\rightarrow A'(1-\beta A)=A\rightarrow -\beta AA'=A-A'\] og \[\text{i.e.}\qquad \beta=\dfrac{A'-A}{AA'}\rightarrow\beta=\dfrac{1}{A}-\dfrac{1}{A'}\] Så \[\beta=\dfrac{1}{A}-\dfrac{1}{A'}=\dfrac{1}{400e^{11\pi i /18}}-\dfrac{1}{300e^{5\pi i /9}}\approx 0.0025e^{-11\pi i/18}-0.00333e^{-5\pi i /9}\] Ved å uttrykke begge komplekse tallene i kartesisk form får vi \[\beta = 0.0025\cos\left(-\dfrac{11\pi}{18}\right)+0.0025i\sin \left(-\dfrac{11\pi}{18}\right)\] \[\qquad-0.00333\cos \left(-\dfrac{5\pi}{9}\right)-0.00333i\sin \left(-\dfrac{5\pi}{9}\right)\] \[=-2.768\times 10^{-4}+9.3017\times 10^{-4}i=9.7048\times 10^{-4}e^{1.86i}\] Så til 3 signifikante siffer blir det \(\beta=9.70\times 10^{-4}e^{1.86i}\)

name.text: 10.3.2.2 The exponential form to Cartesian form

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Express \( \displaystyle{z= {@arr@}e^{i{@th@}}} \) in Cartesian form. Give your answer in decimal form, rounding to two decimal places where appropriate: Uttrykk \( \displaystyle{z= {@arr@}e^{i{@th@}}} \) i kartesisk form. Gi svaret ditt i desimal form, avrundet til to desimaler der det er hensiktsmessig:

\(z=\quad\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]]\(\quad+\quad i\) [[input:ans2]][[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text: We use the previous key point Key Point: \[ z = {@arr@}e^{i{@th@}} = {@arr@}\left(\cos{@th@} + i\sin{@th@}\right) = {@ta1@} + {@ta2@}i \] Vi bruker det forrige nøkkelpunktet: \[ z = {@arr@}e^{i{@th@}} = {@arr@}\left(\cos{@th@} + i\sin{@th@}\right) = {@ta1@} + {@ta2@}i \]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Express the complex number \(z = \displaystyle{@zed@}\)  in exponential form. The argument of \(z\) should be given precisely in terms of \(\pi\), i.e. do not give your answer in decimal form: Uttrykk det komplekse tallet \(z = \displaystyle{@zed@}\)  i eksponentiell form. Argumentet til \(z\) skal gis presist i form av \(\pi\), dvs. ikke gi svaret ditt i desimal form:

\(z=\quad\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
We want to express \(z\) in the form \(re^{i\theta}\). Vi ønsker å uttrykke \(z\) i formen \(re^{i\theta}\).

We calculate \(r = \sqrt{({@re@})^2 + ({@im@})^2} = {@arr@}\) and \(\theta = \tan^{-1}\left({@im@}/{@re@}\right) = {@th@}\). Vi beregner \(r = \sqrt{({@re@})^2 + ({@im@})^2} = {@arr@}\) og \(\theta = \tan^{-1}\left({@im@}/{@re@}\right) = {@th@}\).

Therefore: \[z = {@arr@}e^{{@th@}i}.\] Derfor: \[z = {@arr@}e^{{@th@}i}.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

name.text: 10.3.3.2 Analogous trigonometric and hyperbolic function idenities

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Given that \(\cos^2z + \sin^2z \equiv 1\) for all \(z\) then, utilising complex numbers, obtain the equivalent identity for hyperbolic functions: Gitt at \(\cos^2z + \sin^2z \equiv 1\) for alle \(z\) så, ved hjelp av komplekse tall, finn den tilsvarende identiteten for hyperbolske funksjoner:

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] \(\quad\equiv1\) [[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text: You should obtain \(\cosh^2z - \sinh^2z \equiv 1\) since, if we replace \(z\) by \(iz\) in the given identity then \(\cos^2(iz) + \sin^2(iz) \equiv 1\). But as noted in the previous Key Point \(\cos(iz) \equiv \cosh z\) and \(\sin(iz) \equiv i\sinh z\) so the result follows. Du bør få \(\cosh^2z - \sinh^2z \equiv 1\) siden, hvis vi erstatter \(z\) med \(iz\) i den gitte identiteten, så er \(\cos^2(iz) + \sin^2(iz) \equiv 1\). Men som nevnt i forrige nøkkelpunkt er \(\cos(iz) \equiv \cosh z\) og \(\sin(iz) \equiv i\sinh z\) slik at resultatet følger.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Two standard identities in trigonometry are To standard identiteter i trigonometri er

  1. \(\sin2z\equiv2\sin z\cos z\)
  2. \(\cos2z\equiv\cos^2z-\sin^2z\)

Use Osborne's rule to obtain the corresponding identities for hyperbolic functions. Bruk Osbornes regel for å få de tilsvarende identitetene for hyperbolske funksjoner.

  1. \(\sinh2z\quad\equiv\quad\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]
  2. \(\cosh2z\quad\equiv\quad\)[[input:ans2]][[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
This is a direct application of Osborne's rule. Dette er en direkte anvendelse av Osbornes regel.

  1. \(\sinh2z\equiv2\sinh z\cosh z\)
  2. \(\cosh2z\equiv\cosh^2z+\sinh^2z\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

name.text: 10.3.4.2 Hyperbolic function of a complex number

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Express \(z={@exp@}(a+ib)\) in Cartesian form: Uttrykk \(z={@exp@}(a+ib)\) i kartesisk form:

\(z=\quad\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]] \(\quad+\quad\) [[input:ans2]][[validation:ans2]]\(\ \ i\)    [[feedback:prt1]]  [[feedback:prt2]] 

Hint: the imaginary unit, \(i\), should not appear in your final expressions. Hint: den imaginære enheten, \(i\), skal ikke være i ditt endelige uttrykk.

Therefore find the real and imaginary parts of \(z = {@exp@}(1 + {@im@}i)\). Express your answers in decimal form, rounding to 3 decimal places if necessary: Finn dermed de reelle og imaginære delene av \(z = {@exp@}(1 + {@im@}i)\). Uttrykk svarene dine i desimal form, avrund til 3 desimaler om nødvendig:

  • \(\text{Re}(z)=\quad\)[[input:ans3]][[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]
  • \(\text{Im}(z)=\quad\)[[input:ans4]][[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
We use the hyperbolic sum-angle identity, followed by Osborne's rule:\[{@expr[1]@}(a+ib) \equiv {@expr[1]@}(a)\cosh(ib) +{@expr[6]@}(a)\sinh(ib) \equiv {@ta1@} + i\,{@ta2@}.\] Vi bruker den hyperbolske sum-vinkel identiteten, etterfulgt av Osbornes regel:\[{@expr[1]@}(a+ib) \equiv {@expr[1]@}(a)\cosh(ib) +{@expr[6]@}(a)\sinh(ib) \equiv {@ta1@} + i\,{@ta2@}.\]

We then plug in \(a=1\) and \(b={@im@}\) to get:\[{@expr[1]@}(1+{@im@}i) = {@ta3@} + {@ta4@}i.\] Vi setter så inn \(a=1\) og \(b={@im@}\) for å få:\[{@expr[1]@}(1+{@im@}i) = {@ta3@} + {@ta4@}i.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

name.text: 10.3.4.3 Exponential form to Cartesian form (NOT IN QUIZ)

questiontext.text:
Exercise

Express the following complex numbers in Cartesian form

  1. \({@3*mult@}e^{i\pi /3}\)
  2. \(e^{-{@2*mult@}\pi i}\)
  3. \(e^{i\pi/ {@2*mult@} }e^{i\pi / {@4*mult@} }\)

Your answers to (a) and (c) should be given in decimal form, rounding to 3 decimal places where appropriate:

  1. [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]\(\quad+\quad i\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]
    2. [[feedback:prt1]]
  2. [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]\(\quad+\quad i\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]
  3. [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]][[feedback:prt5]]\(\quad+\quad i\) [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]][[feedback:prt6]]

generalfeedback.text:
The answers here are a direct application of the formula, \(e^{i\theta}\equiv\cos\theta+i\sin\theta\):

  1. To 3 d.p.: \( {@sol1@}e^{i\pi/3} = {@sol1@}(\cos(i\pi/3) + i\sin(i\pi/3)) = {@sol1@}(0.5 + i(0.866)) = {@ta1@} + i{@ta2@} \)
  2. \(e^{-{@2*mult@}\pi i} = \cos(-{@2*mult@}\pi) + i\sin(-{@2*mult@}\pi) = \cos({@2*mult@}\pi) - i\sin({@2*mult@}\pi) = \cos(2\pi) + i\sin(2\pi) = 1\)
  3. First we need to collect the indices, \[e^{i\pi/{@2*mult@}}e^{i\pi/{@4*mult@}} = e^{i\pi/{@2*mult@} + i\pi/{@4*mult@}} = e^{i\pi(1/{@2*mult@} + 1/{@4*mult@})} = e^{i{@pow@}}.\] We then apply the aforementioned formula to this expression: \[e^{i{@pow@}} = \cos({@pow@}) + i\sin({@pow@}) = {@ta5@} + {@ta6@}i.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

name.text: 10.3.4.4 Cartesian form to exponential form (NOT IN QUIZ)

questiontext.text:
Exercise

Find the exponential form of the complex number \(z = \displaystyle {@re@} + \displaystyle \left({@im@}\right)i\). Give the argument of \(z\) in terms of \(\pi\), i.e. not in decimal form.

\(z =\quad\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Therefore, find the Cartesian form of \(z^{-1}\). Give your answers in decimal form, rounding to 3 decimal places if necessary:

\(z^{-1} =\quad\)[[input:ans2]][[validation:ans2]]\(\quad+\quad i\) [[input:ans3]][[validation:ans3]]

[[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text: We want to calculate \(z\) in the form \(re^{i\theta}\). We calculate \(\displaystyle{r = \sqrt{\left({@re@}\right)^2 + \left({@im@}\right)^2} = {@arr@}}\) and \(\displaystyle{ \theta = \tan^{-1}\left({@im@}/{@re@}\right) = {@th@} }\). Therefore \[z = {@arr@}e^{{@th@}i}.\] To calculate the inverse, \(z^{-1}\), in Cartesian form we use laws of indices and then apply a Key Point from this workbook: \[z^{-1} = {@ta1@}^{-1} = {@arr@}^{-1}e^{-i({@th@})} = \dfrac{1}{{@arr@}}\left(\cos\left(-{@th@}\right) + i\sin\left(-{@th@}\right)\right) = {@ta2@} + {@ta3@}i.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
